com.ti.ccstudio.scripting.environment

Class ScriptingEnvironment

  • java.lang.Object
    • com.ti.ccstudio.scripting.ScriptEnvironment
      • com.ti.ccstudio.scripting.environment.ScriptingEnvironment
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    ScriptingTimeout

    public class ScriptingEnvironment
extends com.ti.ccstudio.scripting.ScriptEnvironment
implements ScriptingTimeout
    The ScriptingEnvironment encapsulates trace logging, timeout values, argument validation and error handling. It is used as the base class for debugserver srcipting and UI scripting.

    Note: When specifying file paths during function calls, the slashes need to be represented using '/' or '\\' (with an escape character).

      • getScriptTimeout

        public int getScriptTimeout()
        Get the timeout value (which specifies the amount of time to wait for underlying calls to the DebugServer to return). Call setScriptTimeout to change the timeout value.

        The default value will be infinite.
        Specified by:
        getScriptTimeout in interface ScriptingTimeout
        Returns:
        Time in milliseconds to wait for scripting calls. If the timeout value is infinite, then -1 will be returned.
        See Also:
        setScriptTimeout(int)

      • getServer

        public IScriptServer getServer(java.lang.String sServerName)
                        throws ScriptingException
        Given a server name, creates and returns a ScriptServer object for interacting with the Debugger. The ScriptServer object opens and maintains a connection to the Debugger. ScriptServer object are cached based on the server name, and users can use the get an existing ScriptServer object by passing in the associated server name
        Specified by:
        getServer in class com.ti.ccstudio.scripting.ScriptEnvironment
        Parameters:
        sServerName - the server name string used for referencing the returned scripting server
        Returns:
        an existing IScriptServer object if the the sServerNams has been registered, otherwise returns a new IScriptServer object
        Throws:
        ScriptingException

      • setCurrentDirectory

        public void setCurrentDirectory(java.lang.String sDirName)
                         throws ScriptingException
        Set the current working directory for this ScriptingEnvironment (The default working directory is the directory in which the script resides). The folder must already exists or an exception will be thrown. When specifying the path, the slashes need to be represented using '/' or '\\' (with an escape character).

        Example:
        env.setCurrentDirectory("C:\\Program Files\\Texas Instruments\\myFile");
        env.setCurrentDirectory("C:/Program Files/Texas Instruments/myFile");
        Parameters:
        sDirName - the path name of the new working directory. Can be a path relative to the current working directory.
        Throws:
        ScriptingException - if folder does not exist

      • setScriptTimeout

        public void setScriptTimeout(int nTimeout)
        Sets the timeout value (which specifies the amount of time to wait for underlying calls to the DebugServer to return). The default value is infinite.
        Parameters:
        nTimeout - time in milliseconds. Pass a negative number in this parameter to set the timeout to infinite.
        See Also:
        getScriptTimeout()

      • toAbsolutePath

        Parameters:
        pathName - path name to be combined with working directory
        Returns:
        Absolute path name

      • traceBegin

        public void traceBegin(IScriptSession session,
                       java.lang.String sFileName)
                throws ScriptingException
        Begin writing a trace of Scripting calls for a specific session to a log file. A IScriptSession is passed in, which will be used to associate with the logging file. Only logs from the session, and the objects created by the session will be logged. By default all messages of level INFO and above are logged to this file. Call ScriptingEnvironment.traceSetFileLevel(TraceLevel) to change the minimum level of messages being sent to the log file.

        Only one tracing log per ScriptingEnvironment may be in use at a given time. If a log file is already in use, this method will close the existing file and open a new one. Example:
        // Create Environment and open a debug session
        ScriptingEnvironment env = new ScriptingEnvironment();
        DebugServer myServer = (DebugServer) env.getServer("DebugServer.1");
        DebugSession mySession = myServer.openSession("*", "*");

        // set logging files for session
        scriptEnv.traceBegin(session1, "Session1Log.xml");
        ...
        Parameters:
        session - the session object to associate the logging statements with. Only logs from the session, and the objects created by the session will be logged
        sFileName - filename of log file. Relative paths are permitted. Use ScripingEnvironment.setCurrentDirectory(String) to change the current working directory.
        Throws:
        ScriptingException - if the log file cannot be opened

      • traceBegin

        public void traceBegin(IScriptSession session,
                       java.lang.String sFileName,
                       int byteSizeLimit)
                throws ScriptingException
        Same as traceBegin(IScriptSession session, String sFileName), except you can specify a maximum file size (in bytes).

        Please read the notes on the file size features in traceBegin(String sFileName, int byteSizeLimit)
        Parameters:
        session - the session object to associate the logging statements with. Only logs from the session, and the objects created by the session will be logged
        sFileName - filename of log file. Relative paths are permitted. Use ScripingEnvironment.setCurrentDirectory(String) to change the current working directory.
        byteSizeLimit - the size limit (in numeric number of bytes) each log file show go up to before the logger creates a new log file.
        Throws:
        ScriptingException - if the log file cannot be opened

        sStylesheetName - filename of the XSL Stylesheet.
        Throws:
        ScriptingException - if the log file cannot be opened

      • traceBegin

        public void traceBegin(java.lang.String sFileName)
                throws ScriptingException
        Begin writing a trace of Scripting calls to a log file. By default all messages of level INFO and above are logged to this file. Call ScriptingEnvironment.traceSetFileLevel(TraceLevel) to change the minimum level of messages being sent to the log file.

        Only one tracing log per ScriptingEnvironment may be in use at a given time. If a log file is already in use, this method will close the existing file and open a new one.
        Parameters:
        sFileName - filename of log file. Relative paths are permitted. Use ScripingEnvironment.setCurrentDirectory(String) to change the current working directory.
        Throws:
        ScriptingException - if the log file cannot be opened

      • traceBegin

        public void traceBegin(java.lang.String sFileName,
                       int byteSizeLimit)
                throws ScriptingException
        Same as traceBegin(String sFileName), except you can specify a maximum file size (in bytes). When the log file exceeds the maximum amount of bytes specified, the logger will create a new file. The files will be named as following:
        <sFileName>.n,<sFileName>.n-1,...,<sFileName>.0 (where n-1 is the number of files created)

        Note: the following information should be noted on how this feature works:
        1. the order of the files go from highest number to lowest number. So, <sFileName>.n contains the first record, and <sFileName>.0 contains the last record
        2. existing files will not be deleted. So, if there are n+1 existing files, the counter/file extension will start at n+1 and so on
        3. even if all logs fit in a single file, the output will be stored in <sFileName>.0 instead of just <sFileName>

        Parameters:
        sFileName - filename of log file. Relative paths are permitted. Use ScripingEnvironment.setCurrentDirectory(String) to change the current working directory.
        byteSizeLimit - the size limit (in numeric number of bytes) each log file show go up to before the logger creates a new log file.
        Throws:
        ScriptingException - if the log file cannot be opened

      • traceBegin

        public void traceBegin(java.lang.String sFileName,
                       java.lang.String sStylesheetName)
                throws ScriptingException
        Same as traceBegin(String sFileName), except you can specify a stylesheet to use

        Throws:

      • traceBegin

        public void traceBegin(java.lang.String sFileName,

        Throws:
        ScriptingException - if the log file cannot be opened

      • traceEnd

        public void traceEnd()
              throws ScriptingException
        End the log file tracing of scripting calls and close the log file.
        Throws:
        ScriptingException - if trace has not been initialized

      • traceEnd

        public void traceEnd(IScriptSession session)
              throws ScriptingException
        End the log file tracing of scripting calls and close the log file for the session. Example:
        // Create Environment and open a debug session
        ScriptingEnvironment env = new ScriptingEnvironment();
        DebugServer myServer = (DebugServer) env.getServer("DebugServer.1");
        DebugSession mySession = myServer.openSession("*", "*");

        // set logging files for session
        scriptEnv.traceBegin(session1, "Session1Log.xml", "DefaultStylesheet.xsl");
        ...
        scriptEnv.traceEnd(session1);
        Parameters:
        session - the session object associated with the logging file. Only logs from the session, and the objects created by the session will be logged
        Throws:
        ScriptingException - if trace not initialized

      • traceSetConsoleLevel

        public void traceSetConsoleLevel(java.lang.String sLevel)
                          throws ScriptingException
        Control the level of log messages being echoed to the console (stdout/stderr). By default every message of level INFO (and above) is logged to the console. Additionally every message of level SEVERE is logged to the standard error stream (stderr).

        // Turn off all logging on the console - including error messages
        traceSetConsoleLevel(TraceLevel.OFF)

        // Turn on really verbose logging on the console
        traceSetConsoleLevel(TraceLevel.ALL)

        // Log FINER and above (which includes method entry and exit)
        // All error messages still get logged to stderr
        traceSetConsoleLevel(TraceLevel.FINER)
        Parameters:
        sLevel - pass one the TraceLevel to set what level of messages are echoed to the console.
        Throws:
        ScriptingException - on an illegal argument
        See Also:
        TraceLevel

      • traceSetFileLevel

        public void traceSetFileLevel(IScriptSession session,
                              java.lang.String sLevel)
                       throws ScriptingException
        Control the level of log messages being sent to a session log file. Call traceBegin first to initialize file logging for a session. Example:
        // Create Environment and open a debug session
        ScriptingEnvironment env = new ScriptingEnvironment();
        DebugServer myServer = (DebugServer) env.getServer("DebugServer.1");
        DebugSession mySession = myServer.openSession("*", "*");

        // set logging files for session
        scriptEnv.traceBegin(session1, "Session1Log.xml", "DefaultStylesheet.xsl");
        scriptEnv.traceSetFileLevel(session1, TraceLevel.ALL);
        ...
        Parameters:
        session - the session object associated with the logging file. Only logs from the session, and the objects created by the session will be logged
        sLevel - pass one TraceLevel to set what level of messages are sent to the log file.
        Throws:
        ScriptingException
        See Also:
        TraceLevel

      • traceSetFileLevel

        public void traceSetFileLevel(java.lang.String sLevel)
                       throws ScriptingException
        Control the level of log messages being sent to the default log file. Call traceBegin first to initialize file logging.
        Parameters:
        sLevel - pass one TraceLevel to set what level of messages are sent to the log file.
        Throws:
        ScriptingException - if the log has not been initialized or the log level is invalid.
        See Also:
        TraceLevel

      • traceWrite

        public void traceWrite(IScriptSession session,
                       java.lang.String sText)
        Log a message of level INFO to the session specific file. Depending on the values set using traceSetConsoleLevel(TraceLevel) and ScriptingEnvironment.traceSetFileLevel(TraceLevel) this message may be logged to the console and/or the environment log file and/or session specific log file. Example:
        // Create Environment and open a debug session
        ScriptingEnvironment env = new ScriptingEnvironment();
        DebugServer myServer = (DebugServer) env.getServer("DebugServer.1");
        DebugSession mySession = myServer.openSession("*", "*");

        // set logging files for session
        scriptEnv.traceBegin(session1, "Session1Log.xml", "DefaultStylesheet.xsl");
        scriptEnv.traceWrite(session1, "Here");
        ...
        Parameters:
        session - the session object associated with the logging file. Only logs from the session, and the objects created by the session will be logged
        sText - message to log.

      • traceWrite

        public void traceWrite(java.lang.String sText)
        Log a message of level INFO. Depending on the values set using traceSetConsoleLevel(TraceLevel) and ScriptingEnvironment.traceSetFileLevel(TraceLevel) this message may be logged to the console, a file, both or neither.
        Parameters:
        sText - message to log.
